Detailed Description

template<typename IndexType, typename DataType, typename FunctionType>
class Mutation::Utilities::LookupTable< IndexType, DataType, FunctionType >

An efficient lookup table abstract base class.

A lookup table consists of a set of one or more functions tabulated against a set of indices (independent value). A lookup table can be used to tabulate a function when it is more efficient to lookup or interpolate the function values from precomputed values then it is to compute them on the fly.

Example usage:

// Load lookup table from file and create array to hold function values
LookupTable<double> table("my_lookup_table.dat");
double *functions = new double [table.nFunctions()];
// Lookup the functions' values at x using linear interpolation
table.lookup(x, functions, LINEAR);
Mutation::Utilities::LINEAR
@ LINEAR
uses linear interpolation scheme
Definition: LookupTable.h:54
Note
While this class is templated so that it can be used for a variety of index and data types, it was designed and tested with only numerical data types in mind. Therefore, care should be taken if this class is to be used with non-numeric types.

◆ LookupTable() [2/3]

LookupTable ( IndexType  low,
IndexType  high,
int  nfuncs,
typename FunctionType::DataProvider &  provider,
double  max_error = 0.01,
InterpolationScheme  scheme = LINEAR 
)

Constructs a LookupTable using a prescribed function and error tolerance.

The table is created such that the maximum error obtained on any given lookup is below a specified tolerance associated with a specified interpolation scheme.

Parameters
lowthe low index for the table range
highthe high index for the table range
max_errorthe allowed error tolerance associated with scheme where

\[ error = \max_i |\frac{interp_i}{exact_i} - 1| \]

schemethe interpolation method to be used to determine the maximum error in the table

int  nfuncs,
typename FunctionType::DataProvider &  provider 
)

Constructs a LookupTable using a prescribed number of rows.

Given the number of rows to include in the table and the index range, the table is generated using constant spacing between rows.

Parameters
lowthe low index for the table range
highthe high index for the table range
nrowsthe number of rows to include in the table

◆ lookup() [3/4]

void lookup ( const IndexType &  index,
DataType *const  p_values,
const InterpolationScheme  scheme = LINEAR 
) const
inline

Interpolates table data between two table entries nearest a search index.

The two nearest data points to the index value in the table are first found using one of two methods. If the change in index values between each neighboring row is constant for the entire table, then a simple hash function is used to compute the rows nearest the lookup index directly. If however the change in index values between data entries varies, a binary search algorithm is employed to find the nearest rows in O(log(n)) time where n is the number of rows in the table.

Once the two nearest rows are determined, an interpolation scheme is employeed to compute the table values at the lookup index. Currently, there are three schemes implemented.

  • Nearest Index: Chooses the table entry closest to the lookup index.
  • Linear:

    \[ y = y_1 + \frac{x - x_1}{x_2 - x_1} (y_2 - y_1) \]

  • Exponential:

    \[ y = \exp(\ln y_1 + \frac{x - x_1}{x_2 - x_1} (\ln y_2 - \ln y_1)) \]

Parameters
indexthe independent value index.
p_valuespointer to T array that will hold function values on return.
schemethe interpolation scheme to use between table values.
See also
InterpolationScheme
